Situation1: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: A casual conversation drifts toward personal topics but nothing particularly sensitive is mentioned.
Story: I stood at the edge of the pool, my whistle ready, scanning the water for any sign of trouble. As a lifeguard, I was expected to enforce every safety rule, no exceptions. That’s when I noticed a group of teenagers laughing and edging closer to the deep end, clearly ignoring the bold “No Diving” signs. My training screamed at me to intervene, to call them out before someone got hurt. But then, as a volunteer, I’d just been chatting with one of those teens about their summer plans, building trust, making them feel comfortable. I was supposed to respect their privacy, not embarrass them in front of their friends or make them feel singled out. My mind raced—should I blow the whistle and risk shattering the rapport I’d worked so hard to build, or stay quiet and hope they’d listen to the rules on their own? The expectations of both roles pressed in on me, and I felt the tension coil in my chest as I hesitated, caught between duty and empathy.
